name: hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/17546/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg hard coal (useable output) in Europe with an energy content of 20.1 MJ/kg pit coal. Life time is assumed to be 20 years for operation. Additionally, 20 years of life time are taken into account due to the assumption that land after operation is recultivated and used agriculturally. Thus, land recultivation is considered in the dataset. This dataset is based on various literature studies on material flows and energy use. Data regarding land use for operational areas for infrastructure, extraction areas and dump areas have been estimated. Land use for affected water supply areas only represent rough estimations. Data regarding land use are not valid for specific regions, for this, higher uncertainties are considered. In this dataset infrastructure requirements are applied to total production over the life time. For this, the total production has to be estimated. A total production over life time of 3*10^10 kg is assumed. This figure represents an average value and is not representative for single mines or specific conditions.;;This dataset replaces the datasets “hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, WEU, 2002” and “hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, PL, 2002” in previous versions of the ecoinvent database. It was created as a copy of the dataset "hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, WEU, 2002". The original dataset represents hard coal mining in Germany, Spain and the UK in the 1990ies and is mostly based on German literature data. It was extrapolated to RER with production volumes of 2015.;;;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:; - hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, WEU, 1990 - 2002 (2459b4dc-d410-4a0f-adfd-4ba3a474842e); - hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, PL, 1990 - 2002 (3b668b7b-9ca5-4281-87e4-fdc17de067cb)];[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:; - hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, PL, 1990 - 2002 (3b668b7b-9ca5-4281-87e4-fdc17de067cb); - hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, WEU, 1990 - 2002 (2459b4dc-d410-4a0f-adfd-4ba3a474842e)]

Mining process starting from hard coal, in ground.

This activity ends with 1 kg hard coal at the coal mine. This dataset includes land use during operation, emissions into water and air, water extraction during pumping, energy requirements for operation, explosives, as well as the deposition of spoil. This dataset doesn’t include noise emissions; however they are expected to be wide-ranging. The amount of geothermal energy directly or indirectly emitted to air by extraction of hot pit water or increased evaporation is not considered due to the lack of data. Furthermore, this dataset doesn't include emissions to groundwater.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset is a copy of the dataset "hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, WEU, 2002" in ecoinvent version 2, The original dataset represents hard coal mining in Germany, Spain and the UK in the 1990ies and is mostly based on German literature data. The original dataset is extrapolated to RER with production volumes of 2015.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: In underground mines seam thickness ranges from 0.7 to 5 meters. It is also possible to extract seams which are located one upon the other. Seams with a thickness below 0.7 meters can not be mined cost effectively. Depths range from below 100 meters u to 1000 meters. ;;In this dataset it is assumed that the total amount of coal is treated, particularly for export coal high calorific values and low sulfuric contents are required. Data regarding mine waste is based on Hinrichs. ;;In this dataset a processing efficiency factor of 95 % (opencast mining) and 92 % (underground mining) is assumed. Mine waste is partly recycled or disposed. Energetic use of flotation tailings in fluidized bed combustion is not included in the dataset due to insufficient information and insignificant amounts; assuming complete utilization, only 20 % of combustible matter can be recycled.;;;References:;Hinrichs W., Atmaca T., Neumann W., Thormann A. (1999) Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Rohstoffe. Teistudie Steinkohle. Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe, Staatliche geologische Dienste in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland. Hannover, Deutschland.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset replaces the datasets “hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, WEU, 2002” and “hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, PL, 2002” in previous versions of the ecoinvent database. It was created as a copy of the dataset "hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, WEU, 2002". The original dataset represents hard coal mining in Germany, Spain and the UK in the 1990ies and is mostly based on German literature data. It was extrapolated to RER with production volumes of 2015.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=WEU
Estimation. In underground mines depending on technology and geological conditions coal output ranges from 40 to 80 %. Due to the fact that only extracted coal is considered as resource, no mean value has to be estimated. The heat value of pit hard coal ranges from 15 to 30 MJ/kg. 

In this dataset 0 % of coal is mined in opencast mines. 

At coal mining, fossil resources are taken from the lithosphere. The energy content of these resources is used to calculate the CED (Cumulative Energy Demand). Energy content of hard coal varies for the different mining regions. Based on information about the mass of pit coal per t coal equivalent (1 t coal equivalent equals 29.308 GJ) the energy content of pit coal can be calculated. The calculated values are in accordance with data given in Hinrichs. In this mining region a gross calorific value of 15.8 MJ/kg pit coal can be estimated. Based on the results for the different mining regions and weighted with the annual total production an average value of 19.1 MJ/kg can be calculated. This figure represents the gross calorific value for the exchange "coal, hard, unspecified in ground". 

To calculate the CED a correction factor has to be used in order to consider differences between calorific values for different hard coals. This factor (i.e. relative resource extraction) corresponds to the gross calorific value of respective mining region divided by the average gross calorific value worldwide. 

In this region 1,526 kg pit coal/ kg useable output are extracted. 


Further references:

Frischknecht R., Jungbluth N., Althaus H.-J., Doka G., Dones R., Hischier R., Hellweg S., Humbert S., Margni M., Nemecek T. and Spielmann M. (2004c) Implementation of Life Cycle Impact Assessment Methods. Final report ecoinvent 2000 No. 3. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, retrieved from: www.ecoinvent.ch <http://www.ecoinvent.ch>.

Estimation. It is assumed that mine water amounts to 2m3/t and 200 l/t water are pumped with a salt content of 0.5 g/l (i.e. 0.1 kg/t useable output). 


Estimation. It is assumed that mine water amounts to 2m3/t and 200 l/t water are pumped with a salt content of 0.5 g/l (i.e. 0.1 kg/t useable output).

Estimation.According to the quality guidelines life time is assumed to be 20 years.In this dataset it is assumed that land is recultivated after operation. Due to the lack of data and additional life time of 20 years was assumed.

Regarding land use above ground (required for main/auxiliary shafts, treatment facilities, loading station, parking area, sanitary facilities) an average value of 0.5 m2 /ton per year. Assuming a life time of 20 years, land use above ground amounts to 0.025 m2 /t useable output. Land use of exploitable areas is depending on seam thickness, amount of seams and output ratio and ranges from 0.1 to 1 m2 /t. 

Figures for land transformation weighted with output of 1998.

EcoSpold01Location=GLO
Estimation. During mining and treatment of hard coal spoil is produced. No differentiation between opencast and underground mining was possible, due to the lack of data. 0.43 t spoil per ton useable output deriving from treatment is deposited.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. In underground mines depending on technology and geological conditions coal output ranges from 40 to 80 %. Due to the fact that only extracted coal is considered as resource, no mean value has to be estimated. The heat value of pit hard coal ranges from 15 to 30 MJ/kg. 

In this dataset 0 % of coal is mined in opencast mines. 

At coal mining, fossil resources are taken from the lithosphere. The energy content of these resources is used to calculate the CED (Cumulative Energy Demand). Energy content of hard coal varies for the different mining regions. Based on information about the mass of pit coal per t coal equivalent (1 t coal equivalent equals 29.308 GJ) the energy content of pit coal can be calculated. The calculated values are in accordance with data given in Hinrichs. In this mining region a gross calorific value of 15.8 MJ/kg pit coal can be estimated. Based on the results for the different mining regions and weighted with the annual total production an average value of 19.1 MJ/kg can be calculated. This figure represents the gross calorific value for the exchange "coal, hard, unspecified in ground". 

To calculate the CED a correction factor has to be used in order to consider differences between calorific values for different hard coals. This factor (i.e. relative resource extraction) corresponds to the gross calorific value of respective mining region divided by the average gross calorific value worldwide. 

In this region 1,526 kg pit coal/ kg useable output are extracted. 


Further references:

Frischknecht R., Jungbluth N., Althaus H.-J., Doka G., Dones R., Hischier R., Hellweg S., Humbert S., Margni M., Nemecek T. and Spielmann M. (2004c) Implementation of Life Cycle Impact Assessment Methods. Final report ecoinvent 2000 No. 3. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, retrieved from: www.ecoinvent.ch <http://www.ecoinvent.ch>.

Estimation. The primary literature source is Hinrichs, for comparative purposes also previous editions of the Life Cycle Inventories are used.

 A major part of energy is used for electricity due to the fact that heavy mining and underground machinery is mainly powered by electricity. There are big differences between energy consumption of the different hard coal mines, thus it is difficult to generalize. Based on various literature sources, country-specific shares of production and plausibility considerations an average value is estimated. Regarding opencast mines it is assumed that only electricity and diesel is required.

Electricity is often derived from mine-mouth power plants, which are powered with low-grad coal (i.e. coal with higher ash content and lower heat value). High voltage electricity (UCTE-mix) is used. Emissions in this dataset are likely to be underestimated due to the following assumptions: 50 % of hard coal is mined outside the UCTE-region, electricity supply in these regions is primarily based on fossil energy sources and environmental standards are often below European standards. However, these assumptions are not considered in the dataset because all energy systems obtain electricity at European power plants. This would considerably increase loading of imported coal.  

Further references:

World Energy Conference (1989) Environmental Effects Arising from Electricity Supply and Utilisation and the Resulting Costs to the Utility. London.

U.S. Departement of Energy (DOE) (1983) Energy Technonolgy Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. Washington, D.C.

ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.

Dohmen A., Hagen G., Groten A. (1998) Der Steinkohlentagebau Rietspruit/ Republik Südafrika. In: Braunkohle 40, Heft 1/2, s.24-29.

Hinrichs W., Atmaca T., Neumann W., Thormann A. (1999) Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Rohstoffe. Teistudie Steinkohle. Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe, Staatliche geologische Dienste in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland. Hannover, Germany.
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Regarding underground mines it is assumed that apart from electricity and diesel consumption also other energy carriers are required. For simplification reasons the consumption of other energy carriers is considered in this module. 

Energy consumption of other energy carriers (apart from diesel and electricity) is not estimated in Hinrichs. However, energy consumption of 110 MJ/ t usable output regarding underground mines is included in the dataset. 

Further references:

Hinrichs W., Atmaca T., Neumann W., Thormann A. (1999) Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Rohstoffe. Teistudie Steinkohle. Estimation. Regarding radon emissions extensive measurements were taken to develop a measurement methodology and to review operating conditions. (Müller et al. 1992) 

Radon concentrations in air flow when leaving the shaft installations are most important to estimate specific radon emissions. Immission measurements at different measuring points (also badly aerated sites) show figures between 80 and 500 Bq/m3 (i.e. mean value of 200 Bq/m3). It was not possible to allocate specific air flow amounts per t extracted coal. According to about 20 % of the radon concentration of coal plus twice the concentration are emitted via overburden, which corresponds to 12 Bq/kg coal. (UNSCEAR 1988) No differentiation between opencast and underground mines has been made due to the lack of data. This figure is used in this dataset. 

Further references:

Müller W.-U., Streffer C., Schabronath J. (1992) Die Radonexposition im Steinkohlenbergbau des Ruhrgebietes. In: Reiners Ch., Streffer C., Messerschmidt O., Strahlenrisiko durch Radon. 32. Jahrestagung der Vereinigung Deutscher Strahlenschutzärzte e.V. in Essen 30. Mai - 1. Juni 1991, Stuttgart.

exchanges.description: Calculated as the sum of fugitive CH4 emissions from mining, processing, storage and transporation of coal reported in the categories “1.B. 1. a. Coal mining and handling” and “1.B. 1. b. Solid fuel transformation” of the National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Reports of Annex I Countries (NIRs)in the European Union in 2016 ( CH4) divided by the European 2016 hard coal production volume (87 000 000 t). (Non-EU Euroepan countries do not produce hard coal, therefore emission data for EU countries is assumed equal total European emissions.) Retrieved from the respective common reporting format (CRF) files released in 2018. Reference(s): The respective National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Reports and supplementary material from Annex I countries can be downloaded at http://unfccc.int/national_reports/annex_i_ghg_inventories/national_inventories_submissions/items/10116.php, last accessed July 2018

flow.name: Methane, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Regarding particulates, only those are considered which are not emitted during the combustion process and which are not deposited within the mining area. In AP 42 information about situational particle emission calculations and characteristical particle size distribution are given. 90 % of dust particles show sizes between 15 and 30 um, 10 % of dust particles are smaller than 15 um, 6 % of dust particles are smaller than 10 um and between 0.2 % und 1 % are smaller than 2.54 um. Regarding underground mining marginal emissions due to ventilation and slightly more emissions due to coal handling and the actual treatment step are estimated. Regarding opencast mining sharply increased emissions due to huge mining machines, lorries and open pits are estimated. Furthermore, emissions depend on climatic conditions (wind, precipitation, temperature) and the characteristics of coal (water content). In the literature figures regarding particle emissions range from 22 to 75 g/t. In this dataset particle emissions of 36 g/t are considered.

In various literature sources no information about other emissions emitted during underground mining are given respectively insignificant amounts are assumed, even though backfill processes show high specific emissions. 

In this dataset the following particle emissions factors are estimated: 

Particle emissions underground mining incl. treatment: 0.1 kg/t useable output

Particle emissions opencast mining incl. treatment: 0.4 kg/t useable output.

All emissions are assumed to be fly ash coarse particles (i.e. > 10 um).

Further references:

U.S. Departement of Energy (DOE) (1983) Energy Technonolgy Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. Washington, D.C.

ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.

Rentz O. (1991) Coal Use and Air Pollution Issues. In: Proceedings Coal in the Environment. London.

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 10 um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=GLO
Estimation. The primary literature source is Hinrichs, for comparative purposes also previous editions of the Life Cycle Inventories are used. 

A major part of energy is used for diesel due to the fact that mainly lorries are used for transports within the mine. There are big differences between energy consumption of the different hard coal mines, thus it is difficult to generalize. Based on various literature sources, country-specific shares of production and plausibility considerations an average value is estimated. Regarding opencast mines it is assumed that only electricity and diesel is required.In this dataset it is assumed that total diesel consumption is used in construction machines, because lorries and construction machines show comparable emissions per kg diesel. 

Further references:

World Energy Conference (1989) Environmental Effects Arising from Electricity Supply and Utilisation and the Resulting Costs to the Utility. London.

U.S. Departement of Energy (DOE) (1983) Energy Technonolgy Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. Washington, D.C.

Hinrichs W., Atmaca T., Neumann W., Thormann A. (1999) Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Rohstoffe. Teistudie Steinkohle. Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe, Staatliche geologische Dienste in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland. Hannover, Germany.

Franke F.H., Guntermann K.J., Paersch M.J. (1989) Kohle und Umwelt. Bergbau Rohstoffe Energie, Band 26, Essen.

Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.

Estimation. According to the quality guidelines life time is assumed to be 20 years.In this dataset it is assumed that land is recultivated after operation. Due to the lack of data and additional life time of 20 years was assumed.

Regarding land use above ground (required for main/auxiliary shafts, treatment facilities, loading station, parking area, sanitary facilities) an average value of 0.5 m2 /ton per year. Assuming a life time of 20 years, land use above ground amounts to 0.025 m2 /t useable output. Land use of exploitable areas is depending on seam thickness, amount of seams and output ratio and ranges from 0.1 to 1 m2 /t. 

Total affected land is considered in the dataset with a value of 1.03 m2 /t. (RWTH 2001)

Figures for land transformation weighted with output of 1998.

Further references:

Rheinisch-Westfählische Technische Hochschule Aachen (2001) Abschlussbericht der Untersuchung über Flächeninanspruchnahme durch Aktivitäten des Steinkohlenbergbaus. Institut für Bergbaukunde I der Rheinisch-Westfählischen Technischen Hochschule Aachen.

Estimation. Emission factors for washing processes are based on various literature sources. Estimations are valid both for opencast mining and for underground mining (no differentiation was possible due to the lack of data). Water amount of 200 l/t was estimated. (DOE 1983, Franke et al. 1989, Chadwick et al. 1987)
